rsbNotes.title: Luke 1
rsbNotes.text: 1:31 Jesus. The name means “Yahweh is salvation.”

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:27
rsbNotes.text: 1:27 betrothed. More binding than a modern engagement, this was virtually a form of marriage. The couple did not live together, but a divorce was needed to break the relationship. See theological note “The Virgin Birth of Jesus.”

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:28–29
rsbNotes.text: 1:28, 29 Mary was humbled and puzzled that the angel should say she was “favored” (a correct translation of the word sometimes rendered “full of grace”). The word indicates that Mary received grace, not that she was the source of grace to others.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:32
rsbNotes.text:
1:32 great. There is a fuller meaning here than when the term was applied to John (v. 15). Jesus will be “the Son of the Most High.”

the throne of his father. Luke points to the Messiah as a descendant of David (2 Sam. 7:12–16; Ps. 89:29).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:33
rsbNotes.text: 1:33 The kingdom having no end is the kingdom of God.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:34
rsbNotes.text: 1:34 Mary perceived that the angel was not talking about the children she would have in the course of her marriage to Joseph. She understood the angel to mean something miraculous—birth without a human father. The virgin conception is a distinctively Christian idea. Greek parallels sometimes cited relate stories of gods having sexual intercourse with women.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:36
rsbNotes.text: 1:36 your relative. Elizabeth, and therefore Mary, was a descendant of Aaron (v. 5). The reference to “his father David” (v. 32) shows that Mary was also of Davidic descent. One of her parents was evidently descended from Aaron and the other from David.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:39
rsbNotes.text: 1:39 with haste. Mary must have left right away. Elizabeth was six months pregnant (v. 36); Mary stayed for three months and apparently went home before John’s birth (vv. 56, 57).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:41
rsbNotes.text: 1:41 filled with the Holy Spirit. The Holy Spirit enabled Elizabeth to pay tribute to the faith of Mary (v. 45).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:46–55
rsbNotes.text: 1:46–55 This song of praise, called the Magnificat from its opening word in Latin, is revolutionary in its concern for the poor and despised of this world, and its rejection of the rich and proud.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:48
rsbNotes.text: 1:48 servant. The word means “a slave” and expresses humility. Mary emphasizes God’s mercy to the poor and His holiness and power.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:51–53
rsbNotes.text: 1:51–53 The acts of God referred to are not necessarily in the past. Mary rejects accepted ideas of privilege for the rich as she speaks of what God will do for the poor (Ps. 9:18 note).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:54
rsbNotes.text: 1:54 helped. God’s help through the Messiah is probably in mind.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 1:55
rsbNotes.text: 1:55 Abraham. A reference to the covenant between God and Israel.
